Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Trabecular bone ontogeny and locomotor development in humans and non-human primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Analyses of bone structure in living and extinct primates typically assume a direct relationship between bone form and function even though the mechanisms of bone's adaptive response to loads is not fully understood. The primary objective of this project is collecting comparative age-related data on the development of bone from a number of locations in the postcranial skeleton of humans, chimpanzees, and macaques to test an explanatory model for the patterns of change associated with locomotor development in these species. This project quantifies the changes in trabecular bone microstructure and elastic properties during ontogeny in humans, chimpanzees, and macaques using high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scan data in the postcranial skeleton. The relative contributions of locomotor loading, body mass, sex, and age on the development of trabecular and cortical bone structure are examined, as are kinematic and kinetic analyses of locomotor ontogeny in a sample of juvenile modern humans to relate structural changes to changes in locomotion in humans. By quantifying the ontogenetic changes in bone structure across three different primates with divergent locomotor behaviors and developmental trajectories, the role of general developmental processes, genetic patterning, and the mechanical loading environment on bone structure are more clearly defined. The simultaneous analysis of locomotor development, bone structural and mechanical adaptations, and within and between species variation is unique and produces a more concrete understanding of bone functional morphology. Ultimately, this study will provide insight into the adaptive response of trabecular bone to mechanical loads and will provide important information regarding the functional utility of trabecular bone structure in the mammalian skeleton.

This study contributes to the training of undergraduate and graduate students at three universities, results in the production of a large comparative dataset of high-resolution CT and kinematic data for use by other researchers and for incorporation into the biological anthropology curriculum, has direct relevance for understanding the normal and pathological locomotor system in children and adults and will be of broad interest in orthopedics, internal medicine, bone metabolism, and biomechanics, and, finally, the results of this study will also contribute relevant data to the understanding of the prevalent health conditions of osteoporosis and osteoarthritis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The link between bone growth and skeletal loading during development remains unclear. The goals of this project were to describe the patterns of bone development in children in relation to changes in behavior, body mass, and walking ability. We used high-resolution computed tomography scans to investigate changes in the bone structure of children from birth to adulthood, using an archaeological skeletal collection from North America. Bone was analyzed at the shoulder, hip, knee, and ankle joints as well as in the long bone shafts. Our results indicate that cortical bone, the bone that makes up the thick outer shell of the skeleton, follows similar growth trajectories from childhood through adulthood in the leg bones (femur and tibia), but not in the upper arm (humerus). These results for cortical bone suggest that the onset and maturation of walking in young children, and the loads developed during walking, affects cortical bone growth.

While clearly interrelated, cortical and trabecular bone follow somewhat distinct growth trajectories likely as a result of different loading signals and growth responses. In general, trabecular bone, the complex network of bone in the joint regions of the skeleton, displays a more patterned growth trajectory. Our results suggest similar patterns of growth at all sites, affected to some degree by mechanical loading from walking. Bone volume is highly variable within and between individuals while the trabecular number decreases with age and the thickness increases significantly until adulthood. Our results suggest that trabecular bone becomes more highly oriented in response to the joint angles adopted during walking.

The Intellectual Merit of this research lies primarily in the documentation of the basic patterns of bone growth in human children during the juvenile period. These results suggest that changes in loading during the development and maturation of walking are reflected in the skeleton, overlain onto an existing patterned growth trajectory. These data provide a foundation for reconstructing locomotor behavior in extinct species within the human lineage and for understanding general human skeletal growth processes and bone biology.

There are several important Broader Impacts deriving from this research. Importantly, understanding developmental changes in bone structure in response to mechanical stimuli has the potential to produce important new insights into past and present human skeletal health. Of particular importance is the potential to use these data on bone growth in the skeleton to address important contemporary health issues such as the role of mechanical loading, diet, culture, and genetics in age-related bone loss. This project additionally developed a large scale dataset of high-resolution CT image data that can be used in future analyses to address a range of important biological and anthropological questions.
